Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story:
My phone buzzed with a message from Sam: “Hey, can you hop on a quick video call? I’m losing my mind with these IKEA instructions.” I glanced at the clock—my shift as a telemarketer had just started, and I was already on a call with Mrs. Jenkins, who was grilling me about the fine print of our latest offer. Her voice was sharp, “How do I know this isn’t a scam? I want every detail, now.” I could hear the frustration in her tone, and I knew my supervisor expected me to handle objections like a pro, never letting a customer feel ignored.

But Sam’s message tugged at me. He’d just moved out on his own, and I promised I’d be there if he needed help. I imagined him surrounded by wooden planks and screws, feeling helpless. My headset felt heavier as Mrs. Jenkins pressed for answers, but my phone kept lighting up with Sam’s desperate texts. I felt torn, my loyalty to a friend clashing with my responsibility to my job, both demanding my full attention at the exact same moment. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out what to do next.
